channel.title: TI-Calc Questions
channel.description:
I'm starting TI-Calculator threads now for mainly the 83-84 versions. I just want to get back to programming BASIC and making complex calculator programs again.
To start off I want to ask all of you who program or have ever used a program on a TI-Calc: [b] [size=14pt][i]What is/are the most advanced/complex things you can program/have heard of/or seen?[/i][/size][/b]

item.title: TI-Calc Questions
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

The formatting and pretty-ness was removed when I copied it from the software, so don’t mind it.

Define LibPub modexp(p,e,n)= Func : :Local re :Local r :Local rr :Local p :Local e : :rr:=1 :p:=p :e:=e : :While e≠0 :re:=mod(e,2) :r:=mod(p^(2),n) : :If re=1 Then : rr:=mod(rr*p,n) :EndIf : :p:=r :e:=floor(((e)/(2))) :EndWhile :Return rr :EndFuncDefine LibPub findprime(digits)= Func :Local f :Local i :f:=10^(digits) :i:=floor(rand(1)[1]*f) :While not isPrime(i) :i:=floor(rand(1)[1]*f) :EndWhile :Return i :EndFuncDefine LibPub eea(m,n)= Func :Local x :Local xx :Local y :Local yy :Local r :Local rr :Local q :Local temp :y:=0 :rr:=m :xx:=1 :yy:=0 :r:=n :x:=0 :While r≠0 :q:=floor(((rr)/(r))) :temp:=r :r:=mod(rr,r) :rr:=temp :temp:=x :x:=xx-q*x :xx:=temp :temp:=y :y:=yy-q*y :yy:=temp :EndWhile :Return {rr,abs(xx),abs(yy)} :EndFuncDefine LibPub genrsa(digits)= Func :Local p :Local q :Local n :Local b :Local e :Local d : :p:=findprime(digits) :q:=findprime(digits) : :n:=p*q :b:=(p-1)*(q-1) : :e:=randInt(3,n-1) :While gcd(e,b)≠1 :e:=randInt(3,n-1) :EndWhile :d:=eea(e,b)[2] :Return {p,q,n,b,e,d} :EndFunc
Example Usage:
k:=genrsa(3)
modexp(4,k[5],k[3])
modexp(283,k[6],k[3])

Note: I did this using the TI-Nspire CX CAS, so it might need some minor modifications (though I don’t think it will).[hr][quote=“Togasa, post:35, topic:462267”][quote author=CodeForFame link=topic=565221.msg4118452#msg4118452 date=1349385393]

[quote author=HcoJustin link=topic=565221.msg4118160#msg4118160 date=1349326744]
The Nspire isn’t allowed in a lot of schools, and assuming the average age on these forums it wouldn’t be allowed for most of the population either.
[/quote]That’s just not true… The only restrictions are the CAS versions; not all Nspires have CAS.

Lmao since you want a reason so badly how about because I’m more familiar with the versions I said than I am with the Nspire…
When I was in highschool the Nspire didn’t even exist. LOL
[/quote]They still use TI-BASIC… There is no difference (from what I can tell) in the non-cas versions. So, in reality, you’re just as familiar with them.

Also, the Nspire line came out 5 years ago, and for some reason I’m having a hard time believing you’re 23+…[quote author=HcoJustin link=topic=565221.msg4118197#msg4118197 date=1349341922]

Not allowed? I was forced to buy a CAS (although I’m in calculus) Junior year. They are the calculator of choice and all the math teachers orient their lessons around using them in class.

When I was in school we were limited to the 84, the 89 wasn’t allowed because it wasn’t allowed on the AP test or SAT, and the nspire definitely wasn’t allowed. In fact, any CAS or anything with a QWERTY keyboard wasn’t allowed[/quote]As far as I can tell, college board never prohibited CAS… You’re probably thinking of the ACT.

Also, the Nspire has been allowed since it came out, so you’re just plain wrong, even on the ACT. And the ACT is the only one that has the CAS versions of them banned.[quote author=Togasa link=topic=565221.msg4118393#msg4118393 date=1349380374]
I rest my case on why we are discussing only 83 and 84 models.
Can we start with the actual BASIC programming and such now?
[/quote]Your ‘case’ is completely terrible, poorly constructed, and just wrong.

Lmao, here we go with another person that knows everything.
I’m going to say the same thing to you as I did to the last genius, Go away lol.
By the way, my cases are so terrible you probably wouldn’t even want to spend another minute of your time on this thread. Am I correct?[/quote]I don’t even come close to knowing everything… Your assumption that I do is completely idiotic, especially when you consider how little I know about everything.

Also, you’re not correct, I’ll be more than happy to continue posting on this thread, because I enjoy writing programs for my calculators.

Furthermore, why don’t you actually address the points I’ve raised instead of telling me to go away? Is it because you realize that I’m right? Is it because you think ignoring the points others bring up and telling them to go away somehow proves your points and invalidates their? Or is it something else entirely? I would really like to know.

P.S. Who is this genius you speak of?

Read full topic

item.title: TI-Calc Questions
item.dc:creator: @Togasa Togasa
item.description:
@Togasa wrote:

[quote=“CodeForFame, post:27, topic:462267”][quote author=Togasa link=topic=565221.msg4118045#msg4118045 date=1349310823]

[quote author=CodeForFame link=topic=565221.msg4118000#msg4118000 date=1349307088]

[quote author=Togasa link=topic=565221.msg4117983#msg4117983 date=1349304924]

I’ve implemented RSA and made a few simple programs. Though, my calculator has CAS, so it makes a lot of things much easier.

Though, there really isn’t a reason to implement many things, especially when you have the TI-Nspire CX CAS.

True well I’m focusing more on the 83-84+ models.
[/quote]Why? They suck.

Because this is my thread and I said lol…
read my comment:
"What are you talking about?
The purpose of this thread is too actually show how much can actually be done on a TI-Calc. [size=12pt]I’ve looked over every single thread that has anything intellectual to do with TI-Calculators and I’m disappointed in how ignorant the members of this community are to the potential of these calculators. So all I’m here to do is to help others understand more about them."[/size]
[/quote][size=36pt]TI[/size]-Nspire CX CAS

You also said, “mainly” and “focused” meaning that the 83/84+ are not the only ones you want to talk about.

Also, that doesn’t explain why you’re specifically focusing on the TI-83 and TI-84+, which suck compared to the TI-Nspire CX CAS.

See, already you’re straying away from the original topic and do I really need to even post that I’m strictly talking about a particular version of [size=36pt]TI[/size]-calc?
Like for real just leave this topic alone if you’re not going to discuss what we already began talking about.
[/quote]No you’re not… Read the OP and your previous posts.

[quote author=Togasa link=topic=565221.msg4113082#msg4113082 date=1348735452]
I’m starting TI-Calculator threads now for mainly the 83-84 versions.
I just want to get back to programming BASIC and making complex calculator programs again.

To start off I want to ask all of you who program or have ever used a program on a TI-Calc:

[size=14pt]What is/are the most advanced/complex things you can program/have heard of/or seen?[/size]
[/quote][quote author=Togasa link=topic=565221.msg4117669#msg4117669 date=1349242622]

I’ve implemented RSA and made a few simple programs. Though, my calculator has CAS, so it makes a lot of things much easier.

Though, there really isn’t a reason to implement many things, especially when you have the TI-Nspire CX CAS.

True well I’m focusing more on the 83-84+ models.
[/quote]
You’ve also said TI-Calculators numerous times. The TI-Nspire CX CAS is a calculator made by TI…

Anyway, you’ve still failed to explain why you’re focusing on two completely outdated and crappy models.[/quote]
Ok, you’re too annoying now. Just stop commenting on this thread.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Togasa wrote:

The Web Guy:

Along the lines of calculators, I spent a good week or two making a javascript scientific calculator. With the option to store every calculation to an SQL database (pointless, but fun).

Sounds nice, but can you program in BASIC language?

item.title: TI-Calc Questions
item.dc:creator: @Togasa Togasa
item.description:
@Togasa wrote:

rip4d:

An example equation could simply be SinB / (a/SinA) = b

You have to be a little bit more specific
I haven’t programmed a math program, let alone did anything involving math, in ages.
So if I’m correct… the user must input SinB and SinA and possibly ‘a’ and result with the answer ‘b’?
Please list all the variables and their values so I can get to work on this program

Read full topic
